SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: What, to be made a Tooth-picke?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Nay, youle spoyle all, if you interrupt him.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: Salumith, O Salumith;
When first I saw thy golden Lockes to shine,
I brake my glasse; needing no Face, but thine:
When at those corrall Lips, I was a gazer;
Greedy of one sweet touch, I broke my Razor:
When to thy Cheekes, thou didst my poore Eyes call;
Away flew Sizers, Bason, Balls and all:
On y the Crisping-Irons I kept most deare;
To doe thee seruice heere and euery where.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Not euery where good Triphon, some place still
Must be reseru'd for other purposes.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: Bright Go-o-o-desse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Well proceede;
What, at a stand? has true loue got the power,
To strike dumbe such a nimble wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Cry hem, pluck vp thy heart man? what, a polling shauing Squire, and strucke dead with a woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Nothing so, he does but mocke, he loues not Salumith.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: Not loue you Lady? O strange blasphemy!

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Faith, what wouldst thou do now but for a kisse of her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: What would I do? what not? O any thing.
Ile number all those Hayres my Sizers cut,
And dedicate those Numbers to her Shrine;
A Breath more loathsome then the Stench of Nile,
Ile rectifie, and, for her sake, make pleasant;
A Face more black then any Aethiope,
Ile scoure as white as Siluer; to attaine
But one touch of her finger, I'de beget
Things beyond wonder; stab, poyson, kill,
Breake mine owne necke, my friends, or any mans.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Spoke like a daring seruant; harke thine eare;
Doe this and haue thy wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: What, but this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: No more beleeue it: why, tis nothing man;
Only, it asks some seriousnes and Art,
By which to moue the King, and gaine beleefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: But shall I haue a ksse from that white hand,
Which gripes my heart within it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Sir, you shall; tis there, pay your deuotion.

SP.SPEAKER: Ty.
SP.L: Then by this kisse Ile do it; hney kisse
There's resol tion in thee, and I'm fixt
To doc it swiftly, quickly; from my lip
Thy sweet taste shall not part, till I haue spoke
All that your wishes looke for: boast of this;
Y'aue bought two Princes liues with one poore kisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Spoke like a noble Seruant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Nephew, true;
Let him and's follies wrestle; from their birth
We will bring out our safeties; Villaines, we know
Are sometimes Stilts, on which great men must goe.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Herod with his sword drawne, in his other hand a Letter, driuing before him P. Alexander, and Y. Aristobulus, Animis, Hillus, Lime and Handsaw following Herod; Antip. steps betweene Herod and the Princes.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Alex. Y. Arist.
SP.L: Sir, as y'are royall, heare vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Villaines, Traytors, Vipers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: In the name
Of goodnesse and of good men; what hand dare
Be rais'd against his Soueraigne? Gracious Sir,
Let not your rage abuse you; there's none heere
That your word cannot slaughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Giue me way;
Shall my owne blood destroy me? that I gaue
Ile sacrifice to Iustice.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Alex.
SP.L: Yet Sir, hold.
Heare but our innocent answere.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Arist.
SP.L: If we proue
Guilty, let tortures ceaze vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: O my Lord,
Tis a becomming Iustice; heare them speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: What, Villaines that are arm'd against me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Tis not so; Nephewes, deare Nephewes,
Throw at his Highnes feete, these ill becomming weapons;
In this case, they doe not guard but hurt you.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Alex.
SP.L: We obey; and, with our weapons offer vp our liues,
To haue our cause but heard indifferently.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Arist.
SP.L: Sir, there's no greater innocence on earth
Iniur'd then our alleageance: let but truth
Accuse vs in a shadow; spare vs not.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: But truth accuse you? O strange impudence!
Th'art not of Brasse, but Adamant: seest thou this,
This man you hir'd with stone to murder me;
This man with timber; both you wrought to staine
The sacred building with foule Paricide. Is not this true?

SP.SPEAKER: Lym. Han.
SP.P: Most true (my Lord) wee will both bee for∣sworne vnto it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Alex.
SP.L: Falshood, th'art grown a mighty one, when these;
These Slaues shall murder Princes.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: No, not these
Your vilde acts doe destroy you: Speake, my Lord;
Did not you see these in the dead of night,
Arm'd with their weapons, watch at my Chamber doore,
Intending to assault me?

SP.SPEAKER: Hil.
SP.L: Tis most true;
And had I not with threats and some exclaimes
Remou'd them, you had perisht.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Wonderfull.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Alex.
SP.L: O truth, for shame awaken; this Slaue will
Exile thee from all Mankinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: What, doth this
Bristle your guilty spirits? No, Ile come
Neerer vnto your Treasons; heer's your hands,
Your own hands, most vnnaturall: Sister, see;
See, mine Antipater; (or I know, you both
Are perfect in their hands and Characters)
This Letter did they traitrously conuey
Vnto Chrysander, which commands our Powers,
And Conquests won in Greece; inciting him
To breake his firme alleageance, and to ioyne
His strength with theirs, to worke our ouerthrow.
Speake, our Centurion; did not you receiue
This Letter from Chrysander?

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: My Lord, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: And that it is their owne hands, witnesse you;
And you; and all that know them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: I am strooke dumbe with wonder; I should sweare
This were your own hands Nephews.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: By my hopes;
If it be false, tis strangely counterfeit;
The Slaue that did it had a cunning hand,
And neere acquaintance with you: but, deare Sir,
It shall be gracious in you to conceiue
The best of these misfortunes: who, that knowes
The world, knowes not her mischieues; and how Slaues
Are euer casting Mines vp; for my part,
(Though there's no likelihood) I will suppose,
This is, and may be counterfeit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: And so will I.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: But neuer I, it is impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Alex.
SP.L: Sir, I beseech you, howsoere you lose
The force of Nature, or the touch of blood;
Lose not the vse of Iustice; that should liue,
When both the rest are rotten: all these proofes
Are false as Slander, and the woke hew'd out
Only by malice; when w'are tane away,
Tis you your selfe next followes: why alasse,
We are your Armour; he that would strike home,
And hit you soundly, must vnbuckle vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Arist.
SP.L: Besides Sir, please you either send, or call
Chrysander home (whom we haue euer held,
A noble, free, and worthy Gentleman)
And, if he doe accuse vs; we will throw
Our liues to death with willingnesse; nay more,
Plead guilty to their Slanders.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: In my thoughts
This is a noble motion; heare them Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: It will renowne your patience; Sacred Sir,
Let me begge for my Nephewes; you haue said
You tooke delight to heare me; heare me now.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: S'foote, y'are too earnest, and will spoyle vs all;
Begge with a scuruy cold Parenthesis.
Sir, (though I know; in this case, minutes are
Irrecouerable losses) yet, you may
(If't please you) grant them their Petition.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: I'm resolu'd,
Chrysander shall be sent for: ha, how now?
Why star'st thou? why art breathlesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: O my Lord,
My gracious Lord, heare me; I must disclose
A treason foule and odious: these your Sonnes,
Your Princely Sonnes, chiefly Prince Alexander,
By fearefull threats, and golden promises,
Haue labour'd me, that when I should be cald,
To trim your Highnesse beard, or cut your hayre;
I then should lay my Razor to your throat,
And send you hence to Heauen.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant. Sal.
SP.L: O vnnaturall!

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Villaine, speake this againe.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Alex. Y. Arist.
SP.L: Villaine, speak truth, feare Iudgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: Briefly Sir, Prince Alexander, and Aristobulus
Offer'd me heapes of gold to cut your throat,
When I should trim or shaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: From which, thus
Mine owne hand shall secure me; villaine, die,
That knew'st a way to kill me; and henceforth,
What Slaue soeuer dare to fill mine eare
With tales of this foule nature, thus shall perish;
Ile not be tortur'd liuing: where's my Guard?
Handle those treacherous young men; and, with cordes,
Strangle them both immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Alex.
SP.L: Sir, O Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Arist.
SP.L: Heare vs; but heare vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Neuer, I am deafe;
Villaines, that hatch such execrable thoughts,
Vnfit for noble spirits, shall not breath:
Dispatch I say; for vnto time Ile raise
Such Trophees of Seuerity; that he
Which reads your Story with a bloody thought,
Shall tremble and forsake it.

SP.SPEAKER: P. Alex.
SP.L: Yet that man
Seeing your Rigor, and our Innocence,
Shall turne his feare to pitty, and condemne
The malice of your rashnesse: Sir, to dye
Thus, as we doe, not guilty, is a death,
Of all, most blest, most glorious; for, it is
To braue death, not to feele it; and this end
Reuiues vs, but not kils vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Arist.
SP.L: Brother, true;
Let me imbrace thy goodnesse; for I know,
The last gaspe of a death thus innocent,
Hath no paine in it; and w'are sure to finde
Sweetnesse ith' shortnesse, all content of minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Pull, and dispatch them.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: This was well contriu'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: An act worth imitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: O, mighty Sir,
You haue done Iustice brauely, on your head
Depends so many heads, and on your life
The liues of such aboundance; that, beleeu't,
Acts and Consents must not alone be fear'd;
But Words and Thoughts; nay very Visions,
In this case must be punish't: Ancient times,
(For Princes safeties) made our Dreames our Crimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Tis true; and I am resolute to run a Course,
T'affright the proud'st Attempter; goe, conuay
Those bodies vnto Buriall: Antipater,
Come neere me man; th'art now the only branch
Left of this aged Body; which, howere
Disdaind, for want of grafting; yet, Ile now
Make thee the chiefe, the best, and principall.
It is our pleasure, that with winged speed,
Forthwith you passe to Rome; and, in our name,
Salute the great Augustus; say, that age, griefe,
And some naturall sicknesse, hauing made
My minde vnfit for Gouernment; I craue,
He would confirme thee in the Royalty:
Which granted, I will instantly giue vp
To thee and to thy goodnesse, all I hold;
Either in Crowne, or Greatnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Gracious Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Doe not crosse my commandment; for I know
Thy sweet and modest temper: but away;
Fly in thy happy iourney; I presage,
Those which did hate my Youth, will loue mine Age.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Heeresa baue change, sweet Nephew; can you flye
Aboue the pit you play in?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: No, sweet Aunt;
Nor in my flight will leaue you, could I shoote
Through Heauen, as through the ayre; yet would I beare
Thy goodnesse euer with me: how ere I rise,
Tis you alone shall rule Ierusalem.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: No, tis Antipater; goe, be fortunate:
I'ue other plots in working.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: So haue I:
The Kings death and her owne; till that be done,
Nothing is perfect; th'halfe way is but runne.
Ha! who's this? the noble Pheroas?
What chance makes my deare Vncle droope thus?
Doe not giue way to your discontentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Pardon me, it is become my Maister; spacious mindes
Are not like little bosomes; they may presse
And crush disgraces inward; but the great,
Giues them full Field to fight in; and each stroke
Contempt doth strike is mortall.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Say not so;
You may finde reparation.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Tell me where;
Not vpon earth; when reputation's gone,
Tis not in Kings to bring her backe againe:
I am a banisht out-cast, and what's more,
The scorne of those gaze on me: but a day
Will come, of Visitation, when the King
May wish these foule deeds vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Come, no more
W'are partners in your sorrowes; and how ere
The King doth yet smile on vs, we know well
The word of any Peasant hath full power
To turne vs topsie turuy.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Are you there?
Nay, then you haue got feeling.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Sensibly,
And feare, and will preuent it.

SP.SPEAKER: ACH.

LG.L: Come buy you lusty Gallants
These Sples which I sell;
In all our dayes were neuer seene like these,
For beauty, strength, and smell:
Here's the King-cup, the Paunce, with the Violet,
The Rose that loues the shower,
The wholsome Gilliflower,
Both the Cowslip, Lilly,
And the Daffadilly;
With a thousand in my power.

SP.L: Why where are all my Customers? none come buy
Of the rare Iew that sels eternty?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Indeed Maister I'm of your minde; for none of your
Drugges but sends a man to life euerlasting.

SP.SPEAKER: Ach.
SP.L: Peace knaue I say, here's in this little thing
A Iewell prizelesse, worthy of a King:
If any man so bold dare bee,
Vnseene, vnknowne to coape vvith me,
And giue the price which I demand;
Heere's treasure worth a Monarchs Land.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Harke how the Mouebanke sets out his ware.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: O, tis a noble Braggard; two dry'd frogs,
An ownce of Rats-bane, grease and Staues-aker,
Are all his ingredients.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Peace for shame,
Haue Charity before you; harke, obserue.

SP.SPEAKER: ACH.

LG.L: Here's golden Amaranthus,
That true Loue can prouoke;
Of Horehound store, and poysoning Elebore,
With the Polipode of the Oake:
Here's chast Veruine and lustfull Eringo,
Health-preseruing Sage,
And Rue, which cures old Age;
With a world of others,
Making fruitfull Mothers:
All these attend mee as my Page.

SP.L: Come buy, come buy, vnknowne, vnseene,
The bst that is, or ere hath beene:
He tha, not asking what, dare coape,
May buy a wealth past thought, past hope.
Come buy, Come buy, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.P: Maister, faith giue mee leaue to make my Procla∣mation too, though not in rime; yet in as vnsensible meeter as may be.
SP.L: If the Diuell any man prouoke,
To buy's owne mischiefe in a poake;
Or else, that hood-winckt he would climbe
Vp to the Gallowes ere his time;
If fooles would learne how to conuay
Their riends the quite contrary way;
Come to my Maister, they shall haue
Their wish; for hee's a crafty knaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ach.
SP.L: Sirrah, y'are saucy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Fitter for your dish of knauery.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: How now Achitophel; what's this curious drugge
You make such boast of; may not I question it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ach.
SP.L: By no meanes Sir; he that will purchase this,
Must pitch and pay; but aske no questions.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Not any?

SP.SPEAKER: Ach.
SP.L: No, not any; doe you thinke
Perfection needs Encomiums?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.P: O my Lord, you may take my Maisters word at all times; for, being a Phisician, hee's the onely best member in a Common-wealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: How proue you Physitians the best members?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.P: Because Madam, without them the world would in∣crease so fast, that one man could not liue by another.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Go to, y are a mad knaue: but come Achitophel,
How prize you this rich Iewell? If't be fit
Only for Kings; tis for Antipater.

SP.SPEAKER: Ach.
SP.L: The price is, two thousand Drachma's.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Once Ile proue mad for my priuate pleasure,
There's your price; giue me the Iell;
Now it's bought & sold, you may discose the full perfection.

SP.SPEAKER: Ah.
SP.L: There's reason fr my Lord, then know y'aue here
The strongest quickest killingst poyson, which
Learning or Art ere vtter'd; for one drop
Kils sooner then a Canon; yet so safe
And free from all suspition, that no eye
Shall see or swelling, pustule, or disease,
Rage or affrighting torment: but as death were
Kissing and not killing, hence they goe
Wrapt vp in happy Slumbers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Tis enough;
Goe, and as Art produces things like these,
Let me heare from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ach.
SP.L: The Iew is all your Creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.P: Though (my Lord) I did not trouble my braines, yet I bestir'd my stumps ere this worke was brought to passe; I know the waight of the Pestle and Morter, and though my hands lost some leather; yet they found labour worthy your Lordships remembrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: O, I vnderstand you, goe, there's gold.
Now my best Aunt and Vncle, see you this;
Heeres but a little substance; yet a strength
Able to beare a Kingdome euery way:
This shall bring safety to vs, and conduct
Hered the way to Heauen: Vncle you
Shall take it to your keeping; and as I
Direct you by my Letters, so imploy it;
How ere stormes yet hang ore vs, you shall finde,
I haue a Deity can calme the winde.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Th'art excellent in all things; keepe thy way
What we admire, that we must obay.

DIV1.HEAD: ACT. 4. Scoena. 1.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: But is it ce taine Pheroas is so sicke,
As Rumor doth giue out?

SP.SPEAKER: Eue.
SP.L: Madam, he is;
Nor hath he euer since his Banishment
Cast vp his heauy count'nance.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Tis most strange;
But iudgement still pursues him; yet Ile call
And visit his affliction; for although
His vvords accus'd my Marriam; tis his sinne
Not person, that I enuy.

SP.SPEAKER: Eue.
SP.L: Madam, here comes his Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: O, you are wel encounter'd; I am sad
That sadnesse thus afflicts you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: I'm bound vnto your goodnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: How fares your noble Husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: Desperately ill;
Hiscknesse Madam rageth like a Plague,
Once neuer cured; tis his minde
That doth afflict his body; and that warre
Quickly brings on destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Whence should proceed these Passions?

SP.SPEAKER: Ad
SP.L: All I can gather is his Banishment,
Which, drawing something to his Conscience,
Makes euery thing more mortall.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Aduice and sufferance is a ready cure
For these distempered passions; and might I
But see him, I would boldly tender them.

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: Your Highnesse may; for now he's comming forth
To change the ayre, not his affliction.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Pheroas sicke in a Chayre.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Leaue me, O leaue me to my selfe, that I may thinke
Vpon the tedious houres I'ue yet to liue.
O, what a Iourney hath that man to Heauen,
Whose Conscience is opprest with iniury;
Sinne, like so many Pullies hanging by,
To draw the Soule still downward: Herod; O Herod.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Ha, what's this? sure I must sound him deeper:
How fare you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: O Madam, Madam; I am full of miseries.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Discourse with Patience; she will comfort you.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Patience? there is a worme hath bitten Patience off;
And, being entred, sucks my vitalls vp.
Herod, loath'd Herod: O credulous Pheroas!

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Why doe you call on Herod?

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Nothing now:
Was't not a strange thing, that he kild his Wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Who doe you meane, Marriam?
Indeed t'was easily done; but soundly sworne to.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: O, I feele a dagger.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Let not her name offend you; she deseru'd
A death more horrid, and her end vvas iust:
O Pheroas, I hated her for that Act
More then the Scriech-Owle day; and vvould my selfe
Haue beene her Executioner; had not Law
Stept in twixt me and anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: O Madam, y'are deceiu'd; meerely decein'd:
I haue a Conscience tels me otherwise.
O my leaue, torm me not within,
Nor raise this strange rebellion: harke, they cry
Iudgement vpon a wretch; that wretch am I.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: This sauors of distraction.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: A Hall, a hall; let all the deadly sinnes
Come in and here accuse me: Ile confesse,
Truth must no longer be obscur'd: why so;
All things are now prepar'd; the Iudge is set,
And wrangling Pleaders buzzing in his eares,
Makes Babel no confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Whom doe you see Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Feare and a guilty Conscience; nay, what's more,
See where proud Herod and pale Enuy sits;
Poore Marriam standing at the Barre of death,
And her Accuser I, falsly opposing her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: Let not your passion worke thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Giue him leaue; Passion abates by venting.

SP.SPEAKER: Eue.
SP.L: This is strange meditation.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: I doe confesse before the Mercy-seate
Of Men and Angels, I slew Marriam;
'Twas I accus'd her falsly, I subornd,
Strucke her toth' heart with Slander; but her foes
Shall follow after when the Hbbub comes
And ouertakes me downward, downe below,
In Hell amongst the damned.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Gentle Sir,
Name them which thus seduc'd you.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Pardon mee,
I dare not, nor I may not; you may guesse,
Their Characters are easie; for my selfe,
Let mine owne shame sleepe with me; I confesse,
Marriam was chast as faire, all good, all vertuous.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: But yet, shee's dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: So are my Ioyes and comforts: O, till now
I had cleane lost my selfe; and as a man
Left in a Wildernesse, findes out no path
To carry him to safety; so was I
Distract, till this was vtter'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: You haue divulg'd a Mystery, whose truth
Shall sprinkle blood through all Ierusalem.
O me, poore innocent Marriam, let thy soule
Looke downe on my reuengement; for thy sake,
I will so get all Greatnesse; faith I will.
Sir, I doe wish you may dye happy now;
Your free confession is a Sacrifice.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Madam, I thanke you; and belieu't for truth,
The hurly burly which but late I had
Is now appeas'd; Truth's a braue Secretary.
I could not rest before; yet now I feele
A calmenesse ouerspread me; and my minde,
Like a decayed Temple new adorn'd,
Shewes, as it nere was sullied.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Y'are happy Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Madam, I am; for, with this peace of minde,
I finde my breath decaying; yet before
I take this long last Iourney, one thing more
I must disclose; then, all is perfitted.
Wife, reach me the Violl standing in my Study,
Of which I was so carefull, and did binde
Your selfe by Oath to looke to: goe, away;
Tis a new birth that Villany vvould bring forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Eue.
SP.L: More mischiefes yet in hatching?

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: These actions leade you on to happinesse;
And for the penitent man, remission stands
Ready to fold him in her Christall armes:
Yet noble Pheroas, make me so much blest,
To know vvho plotte Marriam's Ttagoey

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Name it no more; ope not my vvound afresh;
Least, in th'incision, I should bleed to death:
I haue too much vpon me; adde to Fire,
Not Oyle, but Water; Seas will not raise his care,
Whose ship lies sanded on the hill Despaire.

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: Sir, here's the Violl.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Here's a little Compasse; but a mighty sound:
And in this little Thimble, lies strange Villany.
Madam, twas once prepared for the King;
And he from me deseru'd it; not from him
That bought it to destroy him: but Ile shew
Mercy to my Tormenters.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: And those deeds
Argue a pious Nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: If they doe;
Then thus I will expresse them: Wife, by all
The ties that I can challenge, or intreate
By oath, by faith, by loue and loyall duty,
I binde thee keepe this glasse till I be dead;
But, once departed, spill it on the ground,
Where nere treads liuing Creature; and (though vrg'd)
Deny thou euer sawst it; yea, though death
Be threatned to confesse it: this perform'd,
My peace is made with all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: By all the Bonds of loue and faith I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Then Herod doe thy vvorst; I am beyond
The reach of all thine enuy; peace dwels heere;
And quiet Slumber sits vpon mine eyes:
I haue no Racks nor Batteries now vvithin,
As earst I had when I vvas troubled:
My nummed feete which late so leaden were,
I could not stand nor walke; haue now such vvarmth,
That I can trauell vnto Paradise;
And, vvith spread armes, incircle mercy to me:
I that accus'd the Queene, accuse my selfe,
And on her Altar lay my bleeding heart;
Where I haue found such mercy in my truth,
That Marriams selfe hath got me happy pardon:
For vvhich deare Sweet I thanke thee: now I come,
My life hath runne it's Circle, and's come round;
Mount Soule to Heauen; sinke sins vnto the ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: O, he is gone, his life is withered:
What shall become of me? I'm lost for euer.
My Lord, my Husband; O, my Pheroas;
Lift vp those eyes, they are too soone obscur'd
From her, that as her life did tender thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Haue patience; tis a fruitlesse Dialogue,
Since to the dead you speake; withdraw him hence,
His Conscience is vnburthened, he secure
On his long Iourney wander'd; and beleeu't,
The causers of his woe shall follow him;
By all that's good they shall; second me Fate,
And let reuenge once murder cruel hate.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: No, Ile preuent you, Salumith shall know,
All your designes, and how your actions goe.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Herod Niraleus, Animis, Hillus, and Attendants.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Where is Niraleus? what, haue you tane suruey
Of all the holy Building? May't be said,
Herod in it hath out-gone Salomon?

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Dread Sir, it may: nay and so farre out-gone,
As Sunshine petty Starre-light.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Come discourse
The manner of the Building.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Briefly thus,
The Temple which King Salomon set vp,
In honor of the God of Israel,
(Being by your great Mightinesse defac'd)
Is thus by you restor'd. The generall Frame,
In height, in breadth, in length, is euery way
Fully an hundred Cubits; and besides,
Twenty lies hid in the Foundation:
The matter is white Marble; euery Stone
Twelue Cubits broad, and eight ith' outward part;
So curiously contriu'd, that not a hayre
Differs in all the Building: euery Gate
Is clos'd in gold, and so enchast and set
With precious Stones; that neuer, till this day,
Saw mortall man so rich a Iewelry:
The Tops and Thresholds, Siluer; and each Barre
Studded with knobs of shining Diamonds.
Close to the holy Building, stands a Court
Of square Proportion; euery way stretcht out
Seauen hundred and twenty Cubits: all the Wall
Is made of massie Siluer, and adornd
With Pillars of white Marble; from whose base
Toth' top are forty Cubits; and thereon
Mounted such curious Walkes and Galleries,
That thence you may behold the Fishes dance
Within the Riuer Cedron: all the Floore
Is pau'd with Marble, Touch, and Iuory;
And on the golden Gate, is finely wrought
A flaming Sword; which, by Inscription,
Threats death to all dare enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: What's within?

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Within this Court, is fram'd a curious Vine
Of perfect Gold; the Body and large Armes,
Of shining Gold, brought from Arabia:
The Sprayes and lesser Branches, are compact
Of Ophyr Gold; more red and radian:
The Tops and Twines, whereon the Clusters hang,
Are yellow Gold; wrought in Assyria:
The Fruit it selfe is Christall; and so ioynd,
That when the Sunne looks on them, they reflect
And vary in their colours seuerall wayes,
According to their Obiects. To conclude;
Such Art, such Wealth, and Wonder in the Frame
Is ioynd and wed together; that the World
Shall neuer see it equal'd: but this Truth
Shall still hang on it as a Prophesie:
Blush Art and Nature; none below the Sunne
Shall euer doe what Herod now hath done.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Enough, th'ast giuen me satisfaction; and forthwith,
In solemne wise Ile haue it consecrate
Vnto the God of Israel: how now;
Why comes our Sister thus amazedly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Sir, I beseech you, for your royall health,
And for the Kingdomes safety, you'l be pleas'd
To heare this Euch speake; and howsoere
Yaue vow'd no more to heare Conspiracies:
Yet Sir, in this regard him; and admit,
He may make knowne what may endanger you.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Whence is the Eunuch?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Belonging to Alexandra.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Let him speake freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: It pleas'd my Lady Sir, this other day,
(Hearing how desperately strong sicknesse rag'd
Vpon Prince Pheroas) for some speciall cause
To goe and visite him; she found him pain'd,
Both in his minde and body; vttering forth
Many distracted Speeches; some against
Your Highnesse person, most against himselfe;
Saying, he had maliciously accus'd
The late Queene most vniustly: in the end,
He makes his Lady from his Study bring
A Violl fild with Poyson; saying, this
Was for the King prepared; and by those
That had least cause to hurt him: vvhen he had
View'd it, and shew'd the venome; he bequeathes
The Violl to his Lady; giues her charge
Of safe and curious keeping, till his eyes
Were clos'd in death for euer; but, that done,
To cast it forth and spill it on the ground,
Where none that liues might know it: this scarse spoke,
His Soule forsakes his Body; but the Glasse
My Lady, and his sad Wife doth preserue,
I feare, for your destruction; Marriams Soule
Hath strong reuengement promis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Tis enough;
Th'ast told me likely danger: Hillus with
Your Guard attach the Wife of Pheroas;
Then search the house; and whatsoere you finde
Like Poyson, see you bring me: Animis,
With your Guard ceaze my Mother; goe, away;
Be carefull, & be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.L: Doubt vs not.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Still shall I thus be hunted, and compel'd
To turne head on mine owne blood? Is there left
Nothing to guard me but my Cruelty?
Then let my Passion conquer and keepe downe
All Mercy from appearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Sir, twill be
A royall Iustice in you: who not knowes
The Lybian Lyons neuer dare approach
The walls wheron their spoiles hang; Wolues we see
Fly from the sound of those Drums, which we know
Are headed with their owne Skins: Sir, beleeu't,
Seuerity brings safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Tis most true,
And I will hence begin to study it.
How now, whom haue you there?

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Hillus with his Guard, bringing in Adda in a Chaire.

SP.SPEAKER: Hil.
SP.L: Sir, tis the Wise of the deceased Pheroas.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: By what meanes comes she thus disabled?

SP.SPEAKER: Hil.
SP.L: By her owne fatall mischiefe: when she saw
I did aproach her Dwelling; first she barres
All Dores against my passage; then, her selfe
Mounts vp into a Trret, which orelookes
What euer stands about it; thence she calls,
And asks me what I came for; I declar'd
The pleasure of your Greatnesse; and with tearmes
Fit for her royall Calling, wisht she would
Obey what I must finish: She returnes
An answer like her fury; said she would
Nor yeeld to you, nor mine authority.
Which anger being ouer; she cry'd see,
Thus will I flye to Herod; and that spoke,
Downe from the Turret did she throw her selfe
As if a VVhirle-winde tooke her: which perceiud,
I made the Soldiers catch her; yet the force
Came with such deadly violence, that some
She struck dead vnderneath her; and her selfe
Bruiz'd, as you see, and wounded: By our meanes
Hath yet so much life left, as may resolue,
VVhat we cannot discouer.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: What of the Poyson?

SP.SPEAKER: Hil.
SP.L: No where to be found.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Twas a strange desperate hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: But a toy;
They which dare doe, dare suffer; desperate Soule,
Doe not play with more mischiefe; but confesse,
VVhere is the Poyson, which thy treacherous Lord
(Hauing for me prouided) did conuay
Vnto thy charge and keeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: Sir, I vow,
There nere was any giuen me; neither had
My Lord a thought so odious.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Come tis false;
Nor can you now outstrip me; to denye,
Is but to adde to sorrow; or confesse,
Or drinke of more affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Madam, doe;
It will be too apparant, trust the King;
Ile sue and begge your safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Tis aduice
Worthy your best imbraces.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Quickly speake;
For I am sodaine in my Cruelty.

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: What shall I speake; but, that y'are tirannous,
Thus to compell a falshood; I protest,
He neuer gaue me any; nor know I
Of any hidden Poyson.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Prepare her for the Torture: Shall my life
Lye in these rotten Caskets, and not I
Dare to consume or breake them? Wretched thing,
Ile make you speake louder then Tempests doe;
And true as Oracles; or else, beleeu't,
He cracke your strongest heart-strings: so, pull home;
Stretch her out like a Lutestring.

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: O, as y'are a King haue mercy; hold, O hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Speake truth, or there's no mercy; higher yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: O, my weake strength cannot beare it; hold, O hold.
I will confesse and perish.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Doe it with truth there's safety, giue her ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: I doe confesse the Poyson; that my Lord
Bequeath'd it to my keeping; that it was
Prepar'd to kill you: but (great Sir)
Neuer by him.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Who then became the Author?

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: Sir, 'twas Antipater.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Mischiefe on mischiefe,
How came shee by that knowledge?

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Antipat! how, from Antipater?

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: Ere his departure vnto Rome, he came
And feasted with my Lord; declar'd his hopes;
And that betwixt him and the Crowne, did stand
Nothing but your weake life, and great Augustus fauour:
The latter got; the first he said should fall,
And vanish in a moment; to which end,
He had prepar'd that poyson; and besought
My Lord to keepe it safely; for he meant
At his returne to vse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Can you tell by whose meanes he attaind it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: He bought it of the Iew Achitophel.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: What did you with that Poyson?

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: As my dead Lord commanded; on the grownd
I cast most part thereof; only some drops
Left in the Viols bottome, with the Glasse,
(At her most strong intreaty) I bestow'd
On the Queene Alexandra.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Take her downe;
This at the first had eas'd your misery:
Ha Sir, Antipater; all this Antipater?
O Heauen! But tis no wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Yes, that Truth
Should thus come forth by Miracle; till now
Mischiefe hath gone safe guarded: but, I hope,
Your Highnesse vvill make vse on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Doubt me not.
SP.STAGE: Enter Animis, bringing in Alexandra, Achitophel, & Disease.
SP.L: Here comes my second trouble: vvhat the Iew?
You haue preuented sending for: false Queene,
That hast disgrac'd thy Sexe with Cruelty.
What Poyson's in your keeping?

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Not any Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Not any: impudent?

SP.SPEAKER: Ad.
SP.L: O Madam, tis
Too late now to excuse it; paine, O paine,
Tirannous paine hath torne all from my Bosome:
The Violl vvhich I gaue you, and the drops,
Is that his Highnesse vrges.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: I do confesse them;
Heere is the Violl and the drops: from this,
What can your malice gather?

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: That your intent
Was, therewith to destroy me. O, you Gods!
What's life, when This can take it? This, this drop;
This little paltry nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Sir, tis false
I neuer did intend your iniury.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: What not intend it? Blushlesse impudence!

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: If you be made my Iudge, I know I'm then
Worse then all feare can make me.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Y'are indeed
A mischiefe too long growing. Sirrah, Iew;
Was this your Composition?

SP.SPEAKER: Ach.
SP.L: 'Twas a worke
My Art brought forth; but neuer did my thought
Touch at your Highnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Who made you to prepare it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ach.
SP.L: The Prince Antipater.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Villaine, th'art damn'd for that discouery.

SP.SPEAKER: Ach.
SP.L: No matter; Ile haue royall company.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: And Sirrah, you had a finger in this worke too.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: No truly My Lord, I durst not dip my finger in your dish,
After great men is alwayes good manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Then you knew it was prepared for the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Alas, I knew my Maister had nothing too deare for his
Grace, and my Lord Antipater I know gaue a good price for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Was this Poyson then prepar'd for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.P: O Sir, by all likelihood; for euer your Physitian is like your Hauke; the greater the Fowle is that he kils, the greater is still both his reward and reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Tis true, and you shall both finde it: goe, hang vp that
Peasant presently; and then cast him into Silo.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Who me, hang vp me? that cannot be good payment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: Why foole?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Because I shall neuer be able to acknowledge satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Away vvith him; and for that treacherous Iew,
And you false-hearted Madam, both shall tast
Of that you vvould haue tendred; equally
Diuide that Bane into two cups of vvine,
And giue it them to drinke off; tis decreed,
What vvas prepar'd for me, shall make you bleed.

SP.SPEAKER: Q. Alex.
SP.L: Tis vvelcome Sir; a sodaine death, I know
Is terrible and fearfull; but indeed,
To those vvhich doe attend it, and doe stand
Constantly gazing on it; who doe liue,
Where it scarres none but Cowards; those can meet,
And kisse it as a sweet Companion:
Tis vnto those a Bugbeare, vvho do thinke
Neuer on Heauen, but for necessity.
Your Tyranny hath taught me other rules;
And this guest comes long lookt for: heere's a health
To all that honor Vertue; let suffice,
Death doth oretake; but it doth not surprize.

SP.SPEAKER: Ach.
SP.L: Well Madam, I must pledge you; yet before,
Ile doe the King some seruice: I confesse,
I did compound the poyson; 'twas prepar'd
To kill your Maiesty; the Plot was laid
Both by Antipater and Salumith:
They equally subborn'd me; each bestow'd
Reward vpon mee, and encouragement:
T'was they which made me to accuse the Queene,
I must confesse vniustly; they, long since,
Haue shar'd you and the Kingdome: that tis true,
Be this last draught my witnesse; for no Slaue
Madly will carry falshood to his Graue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.L: But thou dost, and it will damne thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Say not so;
I know this smoake vvill kindle, and my care
Must now preuent my danger. Animis,
Guard you my Sister safely: Hillus, cause
Those bodies to be buried: you Niraleus,
Shall make for Rome with all speed; thence, bring backe
That false, ingratefull, proud Antipater:
Carry the matter close, but cunningly:
For that poore Soule, bid our Phisitians
With all care to respect her; for tis she
That onely can accuse our enemies.
Thus runnes the wheeles of State, now vp, now downe;
And none that liues findes safety in a Crowne.

STAGE.P: Enter at one Doore, Augustus triumphant with his Romans; at another Antipater: he kneeles and giues Augustus Letters; which lookt on, Augustus raises him, sets him in his Chayre, and Crownes him, sweares him on his Sword, and deliuers him Letters: then, Enter Niraleus, he giues Antipater Letters; hee shewes them to Au∣gustus; then, imbracing, they take leaue and depart seuerally.

SP.SPEAKER: Iose.
SP.L: Once more, I must intreat you to bestow
Much on Imagination; and to thinke,
That now our Bastard hath attain'd the top
And height of his Ambition: You haue seene
Augustus Crowne him; all his great Requests
Are summ'd and granted: therefore, now suppose
He is come home in Triumph; all his Plots
He holds as strong as Fate is, nothing feares;
(So braue his minde inchants him) how at last,
He falls to vtter ruine; sit, and see:
No man hath power to out-worke Destinie.

DIV1.HEAD: ACT. 5. Scoena. 1.

SP.SPEAKER: Anti.
SP.L: O Niraleus; so liberall was the royall brested Casar,
As farre exceeds all thought or iust expression.
When he establisht me Iudea's King,
His bounty did so farre extend it selfe,
That euen his Court appeard a Paradise;
The People like so many Demi-Kings;
Himselfe, the great Vice-gerent ore them all.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Caesar is royall, and Antipater deseruing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Me thinks (as in a Mirror) still I see
Augustus dealing yellow Arabian gold
Amongst the vulgar, in Antipaters name;
So louely were his lookes, so Angel-like his words
The very thought strikes m into a Rapture:
O, I could laugh my selfe breathlesse in conceit,
To thinke on those faire honors we receiu'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Liue to deserue euer.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter 3. Lords laughing, and pointing scornfully at Antipater.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: How now; what Motion-mongers are these? S'death, what meane they? Doe they make mee a Batchellor Cuckond? But that I would know the intent, I could be very angry: but Ile not minde 'em.

SP.L: That's he was carried in triumph through Rome.
Poore Young-man, thy Greatnes must downe.
He scornd (being great) to looke on Pouerty;
But now Pouerty scornes Basenesse: farewell.
Your Greatnesse will haue a cold welcome home.
See how he lookes.
Pittifully pale.
I doubt hee'l runne mad.
Come, let's leaue him. Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Antip.
SP.L: Has Nature stampt me with Deformity?
Am I of late transform'd? Am I the Owle
So lately made, for Birds to wonder at? Is't so?
I thinke I am my selfe; I haue my Voyce,
My Legs, my Hands, my Head, Face, Eyes and Nose;
I'm disproportion'd no way that I know of:
Then why doe these Wood-cracks wonder at me?
I could be naturally vex't, and haue good cause for't:
But Ile be patient, walke, obserue: here comes a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: My Lord;—You are vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Ha, noble Animis; what, gone so soone?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Noble Hillus.

SP.SPEAKER: Hil.
SP.L: My Lord;—Your cke is broke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Ha! whats that? strange entertainment: y'are vndone:
Whom should this be; for me it cannot be? No;
I am a King, and tis a hard matter to vndoe a King.
Psh; there's no Morall in these foolish words:
Your Necke is broke; a Banquerout's Sentence.
We are vnlimited, both in Wealth, and State;
As boundlesse as the Sea; freer in guift.
No; tis not their words can breed amzement;
But their strange looks, gestures, and geerings at me:
Instruct me good Nirale, thou art an honest man;
How shewes this disrespect? strangely: doe's it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Nothing, nothing Sir; Courtiers you know are apish:
Tis onely some new Proiect they haue to entertaine you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Proiects for entertainment! Well, th'are strange;
And I finde something troubles mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: What ayle you Sir? D'yee faint? Y'are wondrous pale;
You change Colour strangely: D'yee bleed?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: A Drop; nothing, but a Drop.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Tis ominous.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: True; and I finde something that staggers me:
I will retire my selfe from Court to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Retire from Court! O, name it not for shame;
Least you incurre a publike Scandall on you:
Why should you flye from that most couets you?
Will you obscure your Sunne-beames in their height?
Couer your Glories in their Mrnings rise?
Those that now geered; then, will laugh outright;
When lookes can put Antipater to flight.
No, forage on; and, lke a daring Lion,
Single your Game; let not pale Feare dismay you:
Appeale for Iustice to Heroicke Herod,
Gainst those that thus contemn'd your Soueraignty:
True Valour in the weakest Trench doth lie;
Then beare you brauely on, and scorne to flye.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Th'ast new created me: I loue this Honor,
That is by merit purchas'd: second me then;
And let the worst of fortunes fall vpon me:
This Gard Ile keepe; grapling this Sword,
(Though wall'd with Pikes) Ile beat my passage through;
And to great Herod make my Supplication.
He that feares Enuy shall be sure to finde it:
But he securest, that the least doe's minde it.
Stay, a new Onset.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Great Antipater.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I, that sounds nobly; why not this before?

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: This cause and this Authority.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: What, betraid; and sleeping taken?
Slaues let me goe, Ile to the King for Iustice:
Ha yee caught the Lambe within the Lions Denne?
Cowardly wretches: O for my good Sword,
And liberty to gratulate your Trecheries.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Your Treasons must be first answer'd Sir;
Til then, you must to Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Ha, Niraleus; art thou my accuser?
Haue I within my bosme kept a Snake,
To sting mee first? Trecherous Lords,
My Treasons?' gainst whom? or, by whom acted?
Innocence protect me: guide me to Herod,
That, to his sacred person, I may tell
The Iniuries Antipater does suffer:
He comes; O happy houre: Iustice; Iustice Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: The Iustice that you merit; hence away with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: O sacred Herod, heare thy Vassall speake:
Consider what I am; thy Sonne: if my offences
Proue preiudiciall to thee; Ile lay my life
As foot-stoole to thy inercies: O, consider,
I neuer was that disobedient Sonne,
That did in any thing oppose his Father:
But with a greedinesse, still ranne to act,
Ere thy Command was past: if these Honours,
These titular glories, great Augustus gaue me;
If these offend my Soueraigne, cut them off;
Raze them from off my head; and let me be
Any thing, but Herods scorne; no misery
Can worke vpon me halfe that troubled griefe,
As does one frowne from those thy glorious eyes:
Let not those white haires now be staind with blood,
Blood of thine owne begetting; euery drop
In me, from thee had being; canst thou be so vnkind,
To cast thy selfe away? O sacred Sir,
I see compassion in your tender eyes;
Weeping for me, that mone your miseries.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Through what a Labyrinth is mercy led;
Rise in our fauor euermore belou'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Rise in your fauour! O Herod be more iust;
As thou art Kng; so be a God in Iustice;
The blood of Babes, cyes sor thine equity:
Remember but his Strattagems forepast;
All which, acquitting, you are accessary.
Thinke first on Aristobul fell death;
Your two braue Sonnes, and noble Iosephs fall:
Next Pheroas your Brother; O, your natiue blood:
And Alexandra, that most innocent Lady;
Vnistly and vntimely brought to death,
All through his poysnous Complots.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: All these are past and cannot be recal'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Let not his smooth words Sir intice you to him;
In stillest Riuers are the greatest dangers:
If none of these can moue you to doe Iustice,
Whose Soules yet houering still doe cry Reuenge;
Ye there is one whose cause must not be slipt;
Though Cannons roare yet must not you be deafe;
But (lke the glory you were made for) be
A King, a God in Iudgement, and in Iustice:
Sonnes are no longer Ours, then they are Natures;
When Nature leaues them, we may leaue our claime:
Be this your warrant, iustly to execute
Iudgement on him, that ha's vniustly murdred
Your Mother, Sons, Brothers, Sisters: if not for these;
Thinke vpon her as deare as was your life,
Your Marriam; you innocent, chast, faire Marriam;
By his false witnesse, turn'd to vntimely dust:
O as y'are great, be good, gracious, and iust.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: All those forenamed were of no effect:
My Marriam; O my heart: hence with the Slaue;
Ile heare no more of his inchanting words.

SP.SPEAKER: Antip.
SP.L: O Herod, Kingly Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Away with him; Ile blot out all Affinity:
O Niraleus, he was so deeply rooted in our loue;
All those and thousands more could neuer worke
Me to haue sent him from my presence: but
My Marriam; O, the very name of her
Is like a passing-Knell, to a sicke man:
For, if to be a King, is to be wretched;
Then to be meane is to be glorious:
The thoght of Marriam, like a Feuer burnes,
Diffects me euery Nerue; I feele within
My cogations beating, things long past
Are now presentd, now I suffer for them;
I m growne a Monster, and could chafe my selfe
Out of my selfe; I'm all on fire within:
O Marriam, Marriam, Mistris of my Soule;
I shall expire with breathing on thy name:
Thy deare remembrance burnes me: who attends?
Gie me some Fruit to coole me.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: What, will you tast some Sirrop, or some grapes?

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: No, giue me an Apple.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Here are faire ones Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Lend me a knife to pare it: O Niraleus,
I haue done cruell Iustice; is there left
A good thing to succeed me? All my Sonnes,
My Brothers, Sisters; nay, the very last
Of all my blood is vanisht.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Say not so; Your Childrens Children liue yet:

SP.SPEAKER: Her
SP.L: Passing true, young Archelaus and Antipas;
Beet yor chrge to see them sent for home;
Something I mst act, worthy my Meditation;
Ile not liue to haue care dwell so neere me; one small pricke
With this will doe it: thus Ile trye it.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Hold, in the name of wonder; what haue you done Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Nothing but sought to ease my misery;
A little more had done it.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Good Sir haue patience; a Surgeon there.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Patience, thou seest I haue, to kill my selfe;
I shall ere long rest in my Marriams armes:
I would not be a King another yeare,
For both the Crownes of Iuda and of Rome:
Prouide my Bed, I'm faint and something sicke:
Antipater, be close, Ile sift your knauery;
A King has eye-balls that can pierce through stone;
His very lookes, shall make the Slaue confesse,
Who's iust, and who's vniust: all is not well;
Lend me your hands, wee'l try who is the strongest;
A wager, of vs two, I liue the longest.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Antipater, Hillus and a Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Hil.
SP.L: These are (my Lord) your Lodgings; here you may
Rest at your noble pleasure; when you call,
W'are ready to attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Why tis well;
Yet, if a man should aske this Chambers name,
You would call it a Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Hil.
SP.L: Tis no lesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Then Gentlemen I thanke you; take your ease.
Neuer till now hadst thou Antipater,
True cause t'account with wisedome; all thy Life
Ha's beene but sport and Tennis-play: but this,
O this is Serio Ioco, such a Game,
As cals thy Life in question; nay, thy Fame;
Thy Vertue, Praise, and Reputation:
What art thou now? a Prisoner; that's a Slaue:
Nay, Slaue to Slaues; slauish extremity!
But now a King; but now a Cast-away;
Crown'd, and vncrown'd; and vndone euery way:
Where's now my hellish Counsellors? my hope?
My strong bewitcht perswasion? Rise, O rise;
And once more shew me my deliuerance:
Tut, all mute and hidden; tis the Diuels tricke
Sill to forsake men in their misery;
And I am pleas'd they doe so: let none share
Either in my downefall, or welfare.
Keeper, welcome: what newes hath ill lucke now?

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Strange Sir, and heauy; Rumour saith, the King
Hath slaine himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Ha, cal'st thou that ill newes?
What, is he dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Tis strongly so reported.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Thou dost not mocke my Fortune; prethee speake,
Speake, and speake freely; thou hadst wont to loue
And ioy in what did please me: say; Is the King dead indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Vpon my life, tis firmely so reported.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Excellent, excellent; noble, happy newes;
Why, what heart could wish better? I am traunc't
And rapt with admiration; why, I knew
Fortune durst not forsake me: now hee's dead,
I may say, as the Diuell sayes, all's mine:
My hopes, my thoughts, my wishes; prethee ioy
Doe not too much orecome me: once againe,
Say, is he dead? is Herod vanished?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.L: Questionles, so talkes Rumour.

SP.SPEAKER: Antip.
SP.L: Name it truth;
Doe not abuse a thing so excellent:
And now hee's dead; who thinkst thou is the King?

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: I thinke your Greatnesse only.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Why, tis true;
Exceeding true; who, but Antipater:
Hath not Augustus chose me? set the Crowne
Here? here, my Animis? hath not publique Rome
Stil'd me the King of luda? is there left
Any of Casmonani; or the Seede
Which they doe call the holy Israel?
No, I haue sent them packing; th'are as dead
As Herod and my feares are: O, my Ioyes,
How nimble haue you made me! To behold
The Hangman hang himselfe; would it not please
Those that stood neere the Gallowes: by my Life,
(Which this sweet newes hath lengthened) had I seene
The Old man kill himselfe; I thinke I should
Haue burst my sides with laughing: Come, let's goe;
Ile haue the Crowne imediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Go, my Lord, whither?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Vnto the Court, the City, any where;
Whither my pleasure leads me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Pardon me;
I haue not that Commission.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: How; not that Commission? S'foot, dare any heart
Harbor a thought 'gainst me? Come, th'art wise;
Open thy Dores vnto me; I haue power
That knowes, and can requit thee; by this hand,
If thou withstandst my purpose; looke to be
Despis'd and wretched.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Good my Lord, be pleas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Not to haue you dispute my sufferance:
Come will you let me goe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Sir, I dare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Expect a damned mischiefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Take better thoughts,
And good my Lord conceiue, this is but Newes;
It may be true, or false, or any way.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You will not let me go then?

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Would I could;
Yet if you will take patience, with all hast
Ile flye vnto the Court: if there I finde
The Newes be firme and certaine; I'm your Slaue:
You shall dispose your selfe, and me and all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Poxe of your purity, your Ginger-bread,
And nice, safe reseruations: but, since force
Makes me obay you; goe, away, be gone;
Flye as thou lookst for fauour.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: I am vanisht.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: O, what a thing is Man! how quickly made
And mar'd, and yet againe reedified,
All with a breath; to make vs know, in Kings,
Consists the great worke of Creation:
Why, I was lost but now; and now againe,
Am found as great as euer; thus can Fate
Change and rechange at pleasure; he that would
Haue kil'd, is kil'd in killing: foolish Fiends,
You are deceiu'd to leaue me; I shall liue
To make you bound to mine Iniquity;
Indeed I shall; and make Posterity
Cite onely my example; then (my Soule)
Sit, and sleepe out thy dangers.

DIV1.STAGE: Antipater sits downe and slumbers; then, Enter Herod, Augustus, Niraleus, Archelaus, Antipas, and Hillus.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: O royall Caesar, this grace thus perform'd
In my poore Visitation; makes my Soule
A Bondslaue to thy Vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: Tis no more
Then what your worth may challenge; onely Sir,
This violence on your person, by your selfe,
Must craue my reprehension.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Tis but fit:
Yet royall Caesar, what should Nature doe;
When, like to me, its growne vnnaturall?
Turn'd a deuouring Serpent; eating vp
The whole Frye it ingendred; nay, the armes
And branches of it's body. Sir, 'twas I
That kil'd the vertuous high Priest Aristobulus;
SP.STAGE: Enter E. Aristobulus, and Q. Alexandra like Ghosts.
SP.L: See where he comes bright Angel-like: O stay,
Doe not afflict me further: how he moues
Like gentle ayre about me: see, to him,
Enters his royall Mother; hold, O hold;
I doe confesse my vengeance, and will shed
My life-bloud to appease you.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: Why, this is
But fancy which torments you; here appeares
Nothing that's strange about vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: See my Sonnes;
SP.STAGE: Enter P. Alexander, Y. Aristobulus, and Marriam.
SP.L: My louely Boyes; tis true, I murder'd you;
Come, take reuenge, and spare not: art thou there;
O, let me flye and catch thee: bee'st thou Flame,
Blastings, or mortall Sicknesse; yet I dare
Leape and imbrace my dearest Marriam:
Marriam, O Marriam; Villnes, let me goe;
You shall not hold me from her: O, a Sword,
A Sword for Heauens mercy; for, but death,
Nothing can ioyne me to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: This is strange;
Nor haue I seene Passion more powerfull: See you hold him fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Shall I not reach my comfort? then, O come
You that my wrath hath iniur'd; sticke, sticke here
The Arrowes of your Poyson: so; it workes, it workes.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: A Slumber ouertakes him.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: Let him rest.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter, like Ghosts, Pheroas Achitophel, Disease & Tryphon.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Hold, O hold; whither is courage vanish't? Poxe of feares,
And Dreames imaginations: shall I turne
Coward whilst I am sleeping? No, Ile laugh
Euen in my Graue, at all my Villames:
Yes, in despight of thee, and thee, and both
Your damned base Brauadoes: ha, ha, ha;
My Mountebanke and s Zany! How can Hell
Spare such neate skipping Raskals? What, my fine
Neate shauing amorous Barber! See, I dare
Face, and out-face yee all; I Death himselfe;
For, none of you, but dyed most worthily.
Ha, I am now transfigur'd: stand away;
Accuse me not you blessed Innocents:
O, you doe breake my brest vp, teare my Soule;
And burne Offence to an Anatomy:
I know my mischiefe slew you; giue me leaue,
And Ile become both Priest and Sacrifice:
They will not haue mine Offering: see, th'are gone;
And I am onely fool'd with Visions.
Sit, and sleepe out Phantasmas.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha;
This Vision doth not scarre me; that you fell,
'Twas Istice and my Vertue; all your threats
Doe but augment my Triumph: go, pack hence;
I grieue for naught but iniur'd innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Where is the King my Maister?

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: What's thy will?

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Emperiall Sir, Tis from Antipater.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Antipater? speake forth, I heare thee; that's a sound
Euer craues mine attention.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Gracious Sir,
The rumour of your death, when it had fild
The City; flew to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Yes, and then
How tooke he my departing? Come, I see
Strange things in thy deliuerance: speake, speake free;
How tooke he that sad Message?

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Not toth' heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: No 'twas enough the count'nance languished.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: That was as light as any.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: On thy life
Tell me his whole demeanour.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Sir, in briefe;
When I had told the fatall Accident
Both of your wound and dying; sodaine mirth
Ranne through him like a Lightning; and he seemd
Onely a flame of Iest and Merriment:
His ioy was past example; and he swore,
His sinnes had made him King of Israel:
What shall I say; if threatnings or reward
Could but haue bought his freedome; at my choyce
Lay all my heart could number.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Peace, no more;
I thinke what thou canst vtter: O, this Sonne,
This Bastard Sonne hath onely ruind me:
Hell neuer knew his equall; all my sinnes
Are but the seeds he planted: fie, O fie.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: Do not afflict your selfe; tis Iustice now
Shall take the Cause in handling: Captaines harke,
And harke Niraleus, doe as I command;
Be vigilant and serious: goe, away.

DIV1.STAGE: Whisper, & Exe. Animis, Niraleus & the Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: It shall be so; these Visions are to me,
Like Old-wiues Tales, or Dreames of Goblins;
And shall passe like them, scorn'd and iested at:
Why, what to me is Conscience? if I could
Neglect it in my whole Course; shall I now
Now when the Goale is gotten, stand affraid
Of such poore morall Shadowes? No, tis here,
Harden'd by Hell and Custome which shall keepe
And out-face all such Battry: I'm my selfe,
A King, a royall King; and that deare Ioy
Shall bury all Offences: Herod's dead;
And in his Graue, sleepe my distemperance.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Niraleus, Animis bearing a Crowne, and a Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Health to the King of Iuda.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Ha, what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Long life vnto the King Antipater.
Is the newes true then? is the Old man dead?
The wretched poore Old man; and, haue my Starres
Made me the man I wisht for? O, you are
My Nightingales of comfort, and shall sing
Notes farre aboue your Fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Sir, hee's dead;
And in his death hath giuen you all, that Rome
Before confirm'd vpon you; which we thus
Fixe on your sacred Temples; onely craue,
You will be pleas'd (as Herod did desire)
That ere you do ascend the Soueraigne Chayre,
First to behold his Body, and on it
Bestow one Teare or naturall Sacrifice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: O tis a Rent most ready; Teares in me
Are like Showers in the Spring time, euer blacke;
But neuer farre from Sunshine: Come, I haue
A longing heart and busie thoughts, which knowes
There's much to doe in little time: away:
I long to meet my glory; neuer hower
Was Crown'd with better fate, or stronger power.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Hillus, Officers with the Scaffold, & the Executioner.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: This Preparation's honest; so dispatch,
And place these mortall Triumphs handsomely:
Sirrah, conceale your person; let no feare
Make his feare grow too early.

SP.SPEAKER: Exe.
SP.L: Tis, my Lord,
My part to couch like Mischiefe, close, but sure;
When I breake out I'm fatall.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Thou speakst truth;
Would this day did not need thee: tis a world
To thinke how strong our cares are; and how weake
All things which doe but looke like comfort: there's
Not left in me a shadow; not a breath
Of any hope hereafter; this Bastards faith,
On which so much I doted, to be lost
Thus against kinde and nature; tis a sinne,
That teares my heart in pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: Say not so;
Tis rather comfort well discouered:
But peace; see th'are approaching.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Antipater, Niraleus, Animis, and the Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: Giue way, stand backe; roome for the King of Iuda.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: No, let them throng about me; and behold
Their glory, and Redeemer, Ha; what's this? a Vision?
tall Prodigie: the King is liuing: O, I'm lost
Past hope, and past imagination; by his side
The Emperour Augustus: then I see,
There is no way, but to destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: Yes, to deserue destruction: wretched thing;
Thou scorne of all are scorned; see, I liue
Only to sound thy Iudgement: thou, that thought'st
To build thy Throane vpon my Sepulchre;
See how th'art dasht in pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Gracious Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: Labour not for excuses; you haue runne
A strange Cariere in Villany; and thrust
All goodnesse from you with such violence,
That Mercy dares not helpe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yet, my Lord,
Heare mine vnfaigned Answere.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: In thy brest
Was neuer thing lookt like Simplicity;
Thou hast made Goodnesse wretched, and defam'd
All vertuous things that grac'd Nobility;
Th'ast eate my blood vp; made my loathed life
Onely a Scale to reach Confusion;
Of these things I accuse thee; this I proue
Both by my Life, my Death, and Infamie;
And for this thou must perish: One, call forth
The Minister of death; and in my view,
Some minutes ere my dying; let me see
His head tane from his body.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Sir, O Sir;
Thinke that you are a Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: No, a King,
And thence ordain'd for Iustice; to put backe
Ought of that heauenly Office, were to throw
Mountaines ith face of Iupiter; know y'are lost,
Lost to all Mankinde and Mortality:
Therefore to make your last houre better seeme,
Then all that went before it; what you know
Of Treasons vnreuealed; lay them forth:
The worke will well become you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Is there no mercy?

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: Not vpon earth; nor for Antipater.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Then farewell Hope for euer; welcome Death;
I, that haue made thee as mine Instrument,
Will make thee my Companion; and, I thus
Ascend and come to meete thee: Here I am
A Monarch ouer all that looke on mee,
And doe despise what all you tremble at:
Sir, it is true, I meant your Tragedy;
Did quite roote out you Issue; and if life
Had held, would haue wipte out your Memory:
This I confesse; and to this had no helpe;
But mine ill thoughts and wicked Salumiths.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: Was she assistant to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Sir, shee was.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: Produce her presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Ani.
SP.L: Sir, tis too late;
The heart-strong Lady once imprisoned,
Forsooke all foode, all comfort, and with sighes,
Broke her poore heart in sunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: And that word
Hath brought mine vnto cracking; strike, O strike;
Dispatch the Execution; or mine eyes
Will not continue to behold the grace
Of the reuenge I thrist for.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Feare me not;
I am as swift in my desire of death,
As you are in your longings: Come, thou friend
To great mens Feares, and poore mens Miseries,
Strike, and strike home with boldnesse; here's a Life
Thy steele may quench, not conquer; for the thought
Exceeds all mortall Imitation:
Greatnesse grew in my Cradle; with my Blood,
Twas fed to mature ripenesse; on my Graue,
It shall, to all the Ages of the World,
Liue in eternall dreadfull Epitaphs:
This seruice men shall doe me; and my name
Remaine a Bug-beare to Ambition. Come; I am now prepar'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Exe.
SP.L: Sir, will you please to kneele.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: What to thy vildnes? Slaue, Ile stand as high
And strong as is a Mountaine; strike, or perish.

SP.SPEAKER: Exe.
SP.L: I cannot then Sir doe mine Office.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Salumith betweene two Furies, wauing a Torch.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Poxe of your forme in these extremities.
What art thou there, poore tortur'd Wickednes?
And dost thou waft me to thee? Then, I come;
I stoope, I fall, I will doe any thing;
me as Destiny: O stay,
My quicke Soule shall oretake thee: for, but we,
Neuer two reacht the height of Villany.
Strike, O strike.

SP.SPEAKER: Her.
SP.L: O-o-o-

DIV1.STAGE: Here the Executioner strikes, and Herod dies.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: Whence came that deadly groane.

SP.SPEAKER: Nir.
SP.L: From the King; the blow the Hangman gaue Antipater,
Tooke his life in the Instant: Sir, hee's dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: The Gods haue shewd their wonders; some withdraw
The Bodies and interre them: that; where none
May pittie or lament him: th'other so;
As all men may admire him: for the Crowne,
Thus I bestow it on young Archelaus:
Rome makes thee King of Iuda; and erects
Thy Chayre and Throane within Ierusalem.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Long liue Archelaus, King of Ierusalem.

SP.SPEAKER: Arch.
SP.L: I will be Caesars seruant; and my life,
I hope shall purge these woes from Israell.

SP.SPEAKER: Aug.
SP.L: Tis a sweet royall Promise; prosper in't;
Make Vertue thy Companion: for we see,
She builds their ruines, spring from Tyrannie.

LG.L: Y'Aue heard a Tale, which not a noble Eare
But ha's drunke with deuotion; and how ere
It scant in phraze or action; yet it may
Ranke with some others, and be held a Play,
Though not the best, nor worst; yet wee hope
It keepes the middle passage; thats the scope
Of our Ambition: But, of this w'are bold,
A truer Story nere was writ, or told:
If Enuy hurt it, tis our Fates; and we
Begge but your hands, for the Recouerie.
